title: Jim Dwyer (baseball)
text:
James Edward Dwyer (born January 3, 1950) is an American former <a href="baseball">baseball</a> player who was an <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> for eighteen seasons in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) for seven different teams between and . Listed at 5' 10", 185 lb., he batted and threw left-handed.
MLB career.
A graduate of <a href="St.%20Laurence%20High%20School">St. Laurence High School</a> in <a href="Burbank%2C%20Illinois">Burbank, Illinois</a>, just outside <a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>, Dwyer was selected by the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> in the draft out of <a href="Southern%20Illinois%20Salukis">Southern Illinois University</a>, and he wasted little time in the <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor leagues</a>, debuting in the majors on June 10, 1973 with the Cardinals. He became known as a fastball hitter who was used mostly against right-handed pitching, and played all three outfield positions well as a reserve.
Midway through the season, he was traded to the <a href="Montreal%20Expos">Montreal Expos</a> (1975–76). The following season, another midseason trade landed him with the <a href="New%20York%20Mets">New York Mets</a> (). He rejoined the Cardinals for the season and part of , and later played with the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Giants">San Francisco Giants</a> (1978) and <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> (1979–80). Finally, he found a home with the <a href="Baltimore%20Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> in .
With Baltimore, Dwyer became one of Manager <a href="Earl%20Weaver">Earl Weaver</a>'s key platoon players, primarily used as a corner outfielder, <a href="designated%20hitter">designated hitter</a> and <a href="pinch-hitter">pinch-hitter</a>. He enjoyed a good season in , hitting .304 (74-for-260) in 71 games, but his most productive year came in , when he appeared in 100 games while hitting .286 with eight <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s and 38 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>, helping his team to reach the <a href="1983%20World%20Series">World Series</a>, won by Baltimore in five games. In Game 1 on October 11, 1983, Dwyer became the 18th player to hit a home run in his first World Series at-bat when he homered off <a href="John%20Denny">John Denny</a> for the Orioles' only run in their 2-1 loss to the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a>.
In a 13–11 loss to the <a href="Texas%20Rangers%20%28baseball%29">Texas Rangers</a> at <a href="Memorial%20Stadium%20%28Baltimore%29">Memorial Stadium</a> on August 6, 1986 which was the first-ever game in MLB history that featured three <a href="Grand%20slam%20%28baseball%29">grand slam</a>s, Dwyer hit one in the fourth off <a href="Jeff%20Russell">Jeff Russell</a> after <a href="Larry%20Sheets">Larry Sheets</a> had done likewise off <a href="Bobby%20Witt">Bobby Witt</a> earlier in the same inning. <a href="Toby%20Harrah">Toby Harrah</a> had hit the first one of the contest off <a href="Ken%20Dixon">Ken Dixon</a> two innings earlier in the second. During the season he hit a career-high 15 home runs in 241 <a href="at-bat">at-bat</a>s. From 1988 to 1990 Dwyer completed his career with stints with the Expos and the <a href="Minnesota%20Twins">Minnesota Twins</a>.
For his career, Dwyer was a .260 hitter (719-for-2761) with 77 home runs and 349 RBI in 1328 games, including 409 <a href="run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a>, 115 <a href="double%20%28baseball%29">doubles</a>, 17 <a href="triple%20%28baseball%29">triples</a>, 26 <a href="stolen%20base">stolen base</a>s, and a .353 <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a>. In four postseason games he hit .333 (4-for-12), including one home run, two doubles, four runs, and one RBI.
During the off-season, he played from to 1980 with the <a href="Mayag%C3%BCez%20Indians">Mayagüez Indians</a> of the <a href="Puerto%20Rican%20Professional%20Baseball%20League">Puerto Rican Professional Baseball League</a>, and following his MLB career, Dwyer played for the 1990 <a href="Sun%20City%20Rays">Sun City Rays</a> of the <a href="Senior%20Professional%20Baseball%20Association">Senior Professional Baseball Association</a>.
MLB Career Highlights.
.*Dwyer was well-known throughout his career as a clutch left-handed pinch hitter, appearing in over 500 games in that role. He is currently 17th on the list of MLB's "All-Time Pinch Hit Leaders", garnering career 103 pinch hits, with 10 pinch homers and 74 RBIs.
Coaching career.
Following his playing career, Dwyer <a href="coach%20%28baseball%29">coached</a> (1991) and <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">managed</a> (1992–94) the Triple A <a href="Portland%20Beavers">Portland Beavers</a>. In , he became hitting coach of the Minnesota Twins' Double-A affiliate, the <a href="New%20Britain%20Rock%20Cats">New Britain Rock Cats</a>, and remained within the Twins' organization in one capacity or another for the rest of his career. He remained with the Rock Cats through before becoming the Twins' minor league roving hitting coordinator (-). In 2006, Dwyer became the hitting coach of Minnesota's advanced A affiliate, the <a href="Fort%20Myers%20Miracle">Fort Myers Miracle</a>. He retired in 2016 after 11 years as a coach with the Miracle.
